block.p: Dr. Rachel Nicole Weber and Dr. John Willard Slocum were married yesterday at Rooster Hall, a bed and breakfast in Old Lyme, Conn. Angus L. McDonald, a justice of the peace in Westbrook, Conn., officiated.

The bride, 32, is an assistant professor of urban planning at the University of Illinois at Chicago. She graduated from Brown University and received a Ph.D. in urban planning from Cornell University. In 1992, she was a Fulbright Scholar in Calcutta, India, where she studied refugee colonies.

Dr. Rachel Nicole Weber and Dr. John Willard Slocum were married yesterday at Rooster Hall, a bed and breakfast in Old Lyme, Conn. Angus L. McDonald, a justice of the peace in Westbrook, Conn., officiated.

The bride, 32, is an assistant professor of urban planning at the University of Illinois at Chicago. She graduated from Brown University and received a Ph.D. in urban planning from Cornell University. In 1992, she was a Fulbright Scholar in Calcutta, India, where she studied refugee colonies.

Dr. Weber, who is keeping her name, is a daughter of Corinne Weber and Dr. David W. Weber of East Lyme, Conn. Her father is an economics professor at the United States Coast Guard Academy in New London. Her mother is a technical editor at Analysis and Technology, a research and development concern in Groton.

Dr. Slocum, 38, is a program officer at the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation in Chicago, where he works in a program that supports research and education in the former Soviet Union. He also administers a research grants competition on international affairs. He graduated from the University of Illinois at Champaign-Urbana and received a Ph.D. in political science from the University of Chicago.
He is the son of Culver B. Slocum of Champaign and the late Mary Beth Slocum. The bridegroom's father is a manufacturer's representative for produce-packaging machinery in Joliet, Ill.
The couple met at Cornell, when the bridegroom was a post-doctoral fellow in the peace studies program.
